name: sfchronicle
text: Hundreds of bikers ride from Oakland City Hall west on 14th Street, with a few carrying Black Lives Matter signs. https://t.co/tRMdG8JBSz

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: Fourteen inmates at the San Quentin State Prison currently have the #coronavirus, according to the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation website. There have been 518 inmates tested at the prison. https://t.co/pE9haG9mEV https://t.co/kz1t9ijW93

name: sfchronicle
text:
The coronavirus has reached San Quentin State Prison, where more than a dozen inmates have been infected by the virus, according to state prison officials.

Story by @MatthewKawahara: https://t.co/F3S1kbDA7K

name: sfchronicle
text:
Surveillance video shows suspect in Santa Cruz deputy killing.

Story by @MGafni: https://t.co/ywfLhwQTYH https://t.co/fFyYWnn3Ej

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: There were 239 confirmed COVID-19 cases reported in hospitals in the nine Bay Area counties Saturday, nearly equal to the total (241) from two weeks earlier on May 23, according to state data reviewed by The Chronicle. https://t.co/FC9dflHAMi

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: California health officials report 3,181 confirmed hospitalized cases of the coronavirus Friday, the state’s highest one-day total in more than three weeks. https://t.co/jJ9LWYwkyI

name: sfchronicle
text:
A confidential UC report offers a look at how an investigator can untangle a “he said, she said” — between a regent and a student who accused him of touching her thigh — to reveal the facts and weigh them against a coherent framework.

via @NanetteAsimov: https://t.co/CC9rhjIOoZ https://t.co/EIOWPADwuH

name: sfchronicle
text:
Supervisor wants SF to make pandemic eviction protections permanent. Should it?

Story by @SFJKDineen & @TrishaThadani: https://t.co/YDtE3eRM49 https://t.co/YlAPZWlEvw

name: sfchronicle
text: Counties are slowly reopening for business and loosening shelter-in-place restrictions. But what will best practices be? Can you have a dinner party? @DominicFracassa discusses new guidelines released by SF officials. Listen to our Fifth & Mission podcast: https://t.co/YR1Uaxd2pP

name: sfchronicle
text: The number of people killed by the coronavirus climbed to 403,267 as of Monday morning, while more than 7 million people have been infected, according to Johns Hopkins University. More than 3.1 million of those people have recovered. https://t.co/4i5372l5aM https://t.co/mSS8NkOevz

name: sfchronicle
text: Authorities are expected to release more information in a 2 p.m. news conference Monday regarding the arrest of Steven Carrillo, a 32-year-old military police officer who was taken into custody on suspicion of killing Sgt. Damon Gutzwiller. https://t.co/NNOX6gHici https://t.co/nJmHkw6dNm

name: sfchronicle
text: Investigation into man’s killing shuts down major roadways near Highway 101 in San Jose. Officers responded at about 4:40 a.m. to a report of a person shot on the 1500 block of Alum Rock Avenue.   https://t.co/Ep5CUkzTaZ https://t.co/bGOq2LRPS0

name: sfchronicle
text: On the bright side: Good news during a pandemic comes in many forms. Sometimes it’s hugging a stuffed dog, sometimes it’s losing a pound or two, sometimes it’s visiting the airport and not having to go anywhere. https://t.co/vEWaLvX90L https://t.co/Uajno1e1Ex

name: sfchronicle
text:
The newest stretch of the Bay Trail slices along a bluff beneath a racetrack in Albany. Not only are the views spectacular, it’s a triumph of structural engineering that helps make the public treasures of a divided region more accessible.

https://t.co/06h2PWrWuV

name: sfchronicle
text:
UCSF’s Dr. Michael Matthay wasn’t thinking about a pandemic in January when he launched a clinical trial to investigate whether certain stem cells could effectively treat a serious form of respiratory failure.

Then the coronavirus happened.

https://t.co/e2U5POvtej

name: sfchronicle
text: SF chef Melissa King is still in the running on the 17th season of Bravo’s seminal cooking competition show. Here's how the coronavirus has changed the experience. https://t.co/eWhyFfCUqz

name: sfchronicle
text:
Protesters talk about how they feel about this moment, and why they came out to protest.

https://t.co/UJJ1itE5t0

name: sfchronicle
text: “It’s the first project I’ve been involved with where I keep hearing that people are overjoyed. How great, especially now, to have something that causes such a positive feeling.” https://t.co/qgVFJSknuL

name: sfchronicle
text: Authorities in Mountain View said they will end the use of the carotid choke-hold. “After further review, and in line w/ state recommendations, we have updated our policy to immediately discontinue the use of the carotid hold,” police officials tweeted. https://t.co/3avZiE0Aph https://t.co/Az39G758AE

name: sfchronicle
text: Hair salons and barber shops in Contra Costa County can reopen June 17 and indoor dining, bars, religious services and gyms will be allowed July 1, health officials said.  https://t.co/h4SpvzoFtK https://t.co/6PxkUQnadJ

name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda County reported 3,945 total cases Monday, which was an increase of 71 with no deaths, while Contra Costra reported an increase of 38 cases with 1,706 total, as well as one death.  https://t.co/V7BsfHKtHq https://t.co/bq1NA5dYzR

name: sfchronicle
text: An ex-Minneapolis police officer who on May 25 pressed his knee against George Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes until Floyd died is being held on $1.25 million bail, according to news reports. https://t.co/onq2zcSVFf https://t.co/825Zh8R39g

name: sfchronicle
text:
Homelessness in the Bay Area is a complex policy issue. The coronavirus pandemic promises to make the problem worse. 

We want your input: What do you want to know about how the Bay Area is combating the crisis now – and preparing for the future?  https://t.co/Akhh2DV096

name: sfchronicle
text: As The Chronicle prepares its annual S.F. Homeless Project report, we want your input: What do you want to know about how the Bay Area is combating the crisis now – and preparing for the future? https://t.co/RvnV4mPyv4

name: sfchronicle
text:
After closing more than two months ago due to the pandemic, Yosemite National Park will reopen to the public this week with capped visitations and limited services.
https://t.co/y0VrHFhQ1W

name: sfchronicle
text: As The Chronicle prepares its annual S.F. Homeless Project report, we want your input: What do you want to know about how the Bay Area is combating the crisis now – and preparing for the future? https://t.co/bVXIxqXQ3C

name: sfchronicle
text:
Contra Costa County allows indoor dining, bars, gyms, religious services and hotels to reopen on July 1. According to the county's updated COVID-19 response plan, hair salons and barbershops can reopen on June 17.

https://t.co/pqAcOyMF9t

name: sfchronicle
text:
Giants manager Gabe Kapler joins other professional sports teams and leaders in supporting the Black Lives Matter movement, saying he plans to have this “difficult conversation” in the clubhouse when the Giants reassemble.

https://t.co/xBMmY74YUb

name: sfchronicle
text: People rescued from roof as firefighters combat large structure fire in Oakland’s Glenview neighborhood. https://t.co/WR3eWqsDUc

name: sfchronicle
text:
What does “reopening” mean? Can you send your kids to play dates? Throw a small party? @DominicFracassa talks about best practices as counties around the state loosen shelter-in-place orders.

Listen 🎧:
Apple > https://t.co/ooYsBD8oGz
Spotify > https://t.co/sLuTA6BB9m https://t.co/6Kj6DSmxxN

name: sfchronicle
text:
Protests and coronavirus: There's growing concern that people at mass demonstrations could spread the virus among each other.

Here's how to get tested if you went to a protest: https://t.co/TZuvlVypda

name: sfchronicle
text:
Greed is preventing baseball from seizing its opportunity.

via @AnnKillion: https://t.co/577rZ0Cg7z

name: sfchronicle
text:
Forget stimulus payments. Many are asking the IRS, "Where’s my refund?"

via @KathPender: https://t.co/NzNooHdBXS

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @hooleil: “The central conceit of these videos is that the Bon Appetit test kitchen is a fun, wacky workplace...But once you actually watch the videos, it’s easy to see how often staffers of color are sidelined...” and apparently not paid at all? https://t.co/qBnbWAZHRr

name: sfchronicle
text: San Jose police chief Eddie Garcia tweeted that while the police department already bans chokeholds “as a controlled technique to overcome resistance,” it would further clarify to bar the chokehold use of “any body part to apply pressure to the neck.” https://t.co/zyyELqLP4Z https://t.co/QQr2PnQcKx

name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda County sanctions “social bubbles,” S.F. loosens restrictions on dining, retail starting next week. See what’s open and what’s still shut down by county: https://t.co/XDxmHis8UJ

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: Berkeley tells residents to have face covering when leaving home: “Everyone must carry a cloth face covering when they leave home, have it visible at all times, and put it on when others are nearby,” the city's health officer says. https://t.co/1mv8F3ttZC https://t.co/0J8jQtAQSm

name: sfchronicle
text:
Progressives and conservatives alike are quickly moving to seize political advantage in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death in police custody and outraged protests over law enforcement brutality toward African Americans.

Story by @jfwildermuth: https://t.co/ciT3vTS2LK

name: sfchronicle
text:
Suspected killer of Santa Cruz sheriff’s deputy posted criticism of police in hours before shooting.

Story by @MGafni & @serrano_alej: https://t.co/1X35FjKERW https://t.co/H0eXBZXwbG

name: sfchronicle
text:
California school district officials knew reopening schools this fall for the state’s 6 million students, in a pandemic, wouldn’t be easy or inexpensive. But for some, it feels all but impossible after reading the how-to guide released by the state.

https://t.co/gdCcy9ZWCD
